speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the abdominal pain you're experiencing, is it constant or does it come and go, and where exactly is the pain located?

speaker: Patient
text: "The pain is mostly in the upper part of my belly, and it's been coming and going for weeks. Some days it's bearable, but others it's really sharp and uncomfortable. It seems to get worse after I eat or exert myself."

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned the abdominal pain, can you also tell me more about the night sweats, how long have you been experiencing them and are they drenching, requiring you to change your clothes?

speaker: Patient
text: "The night sweats started around the same time as the abdominal pain, about 4 weeks ago. They're pretty intense, I'd say drenching is a good way to describe them - I often have to change my clothes in the middle of the night because my shirt and sheets are soaked through. It's been happening almost every night, and it's really been disrupting my sleep."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you recently traveled to any foreign countries or been exposed to anyone who has been ill, and can you also tell me more about the weight loss you've experienced, was it intentional or unintentional?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I haven't traveled anywhere recently, and I don't think I've been around anyone who's been seriously ill. As for the weight loss, it was unintentional - I just noticed that my clothes were getting looser and I was losing appetite, so I weighed myself and saw that I'd lost about 12 pounds over the past few weeks, which is pretty unusual for me."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the enlarged supraclavicular lymph node, when did you first notice it and has it been growing in size, and have you experienced any fever or chills along with your other symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "The swelling in my neck started about 4 days ago, and it's been getting a bit bigger since then. I haven't noticed any fever or chills, but like I mentioned earlier, I have been having those intense night sweats. The swelling itself doesn't really hurt, but it's uncomfortable and I can feel it when I touch my neck or wear a shirt that's a bit tight."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or experienced any nausea and vomiting along with the abdominal pain, and can you also tell me about your bowel movements, have you noticed any blood or changes in consistency?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, my appetite has decreased significantly, and I've noticed that I feel full really quickly after eating, even if it's just a small meal. I haven't experienced any nausea or vomiting, but I do feel bloated and uncomfortable after eating. As for my bowel movements, they seem normal, but I have noticed that I'm having to go to the bathroom less often than usual, and my stools are a bit paler than they used to be, but I haven't seen any blood."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me about your family medical history, are there any instances of cancer, autoimmune disorders, or chronic illnesses that run in your family, and have you ever been a smoker or been exposed to secondhand smoke?

speaker: Patient
text: "My family medical history is pretty clean, I don't think there's any history of cancer or autoimmune disorders that I'm aware of. My parents are still alive and healthy, and I don't have any siblings with major health issues. As for smoking, yeah, I've been a smoker for about 30 years, around a pack a day. I've tried to quit a few times, but I haven't been able to kick the habit yet."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your fatigue, is it worse at any particular time of day, and have you noticed any difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, especially when exerting yourself?

speaker: Patient
text: "The fatigue is pretty constant, but it seems to get worse in the afternoon and evening. I've noticed that I get winded easily, even when I'm just doing simple tasks like walking up the stairs or carrying groceries. I haven't really noticed any difficulty breathing when I'm sitting still, but when I exert myself, I do feel like I'm short of breath more quickly than I used to."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any pain or discomfort in your chest or arms, and can you also tell me about your diet, have you noticed any difficulty swallowing or pain when eating certain foods? REQUEST TEST: Complete Blood Count.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Complete Blood Count (CBC) results show: White Blood Cell (WBC) count is Elevated, Hemoglobin is Slightly Decreased, and Platelets are Normal.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any lumps or masses in your neck, underarms, or groin area, in addition to the enlarged supraclavicular lymph node, and have you experienced any itching or rash on your skin? REQUEST TEST: Lymph Node Biopsy.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Lymph Node Biopsy results show: Lymphocytes with a high proliferative index that stain positive for CD20, indicating a potential lymphoma.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any difficulty breathing when lying down or if you've noticed any swelling in your legs or feet, and have you had any previous infections or illnesses that may have triggered your current symptoms? REQUEST TEST: Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any neurological symptoms such as numbness, tingling, or weakness in your arms or legs, and have you noticed any changes in your vision or hearing? REQUEST TEST: Liver Function Test.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've had any previous surgeries or medical procedures, and have you been taking any medications or supplements that may be contributing to your symptoms? REQUEST TEST: Computed Tomography scan of the abdomen.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Computed Tomography (CT) scan of the Thorax and Abdomen shows: Massively enlarged axillary, mediastinal, and cervical lymph nodes, and dullness noted over the left lower quadrant, which is consistent with the splenomegaly detected during the abdominal examination.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the computed tomography scan of the abdomen and the lymph node biopsy have been completed, and if so, what were the results? REQUEST TEST: Bone Marrow Biopsy.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: The Computed Tomography (CT) scan of the Thorax and Abdomen shows: Massively enlarged axillary, mediastinal, and cervical lymph nodes. The Lymph Node Biopsy results show: Lymphocytes with a high proliferative index that stain positive for CD20, indicating a potential lymphoma. However, the Bone Marrow Biopsy results are not available in the current data.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any significant stress or anxiety in your life recently, and have you noticed any correlation between your stress levels and the severity of your symptoms? REQUEST TEST: Blood Chemistry Test.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any pain or discomfort in your bones or joints, and have you experienced any easy bruising or bleeding, especially after the blood tests and biopsies that were recently performed? REQUEST TEST: HIV Test.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any recurring infections, such as pneumonia or sinus infections, and have you noticed any unusual bleeding or discharge from any areas of your body, including your nose, gums, or rectal area?

speaker: Patient
text: "I haven't had any recurring infections that I can think of, no pneumonia or sinus infections recently. As for unusual bleeding or discharge, I haven't noticed anything out of the ordinary, except maybe some occasional nosebleeds when I blow my nose too hard, but that's not really new for me. I also haven't seen any blood in my stool or urine, and my gums seem fine, no excessive bleeding when I brush my teeth."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any unusual or unexplained bleeding, such as bleeding gums or nosebleeds, and have you noticed any petechiae, which are small red or purple spots on your skin, especially after the recent tests and biopsies? REQUEST TEST: Coagulation Profile.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any recent illnesses or infections that may have triggered your symptoms, and have you noticed any improvement or worsening of your symptoms since our last conversation? REQUEST TEST: Immunophenotyping by Flow Cytometry.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the results from the Immunophenotyping by Flow Cytometry and the Coagulation Profile have been completed, and if so, what were the findings? REQUEST TEST: PET Scan.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: The Immunophenotyping by Flow Cytometry results show: NORMAL READINGS. The Coagulation Profile results show: NORMAL READINGS. However, the PET Scan results are not available in the current data.

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on your symptoms and the results from the various tests we've conducted, I'm going to review everything one last time before making a diagnosis. Can you confirm that all the test results, including the PET Scan, have been completed and are available for review?
